instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
Hi guys, I have a here a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>

The USB-C meter is going from 5V to 20.5V and is pulling around .12A

The fan spins, and the trackpad starts to click when pressed but is unable to boot

I am getting USB activity, when plugging in a usb-c adapter with a apple mouse the usb is showing activity with the red laser. (on a western digital easystore it blinks the light)

CPU is getting very little warm,

and also <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is getting a little warm, it is under-filled and looks very clean.

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> -
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_VCC</SIGNAL> - 13V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_IN</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.22V
[B]<SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_CPUVCC</SIGNAL> - 0V[/B]
[B]<SIGNAL>CPUVR_FCCM</SIGNAL> - 0V[/B]
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PWM1</SIGNAL> - 2.52V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PWM2</SIGNAL> - 2.52V
<SIGNAL>VR_HOT_L</SIGNAL> - 0.9V
------

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.05V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.37V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.11V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> - 1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

[B]<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> - 0V[/B]

Any ideas? I am planning to replace the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> as I watched other videos from Rossmann and he replaced it, (even tho it is edgebonded all around) and it allowed the machine to work.

Please let me know what other measurements you would like me to give.

Photos attached.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
USB C Amp Mete shows weird activity.

Jumps between 20V & .12A to 20V & .09A
Sometimes shows 20V & .03a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message: External video? If no, probably the usual dead CPU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 50193"]External video? If no, probably the usual dead CPU[/QUOTE]

its not fully booting up so there cannot be external video??

 also, if theres usb activity, such as light, doesn't that mean that cpu is not dead, but instead another chip not fully activating it?

Are there are chips or points I should test?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
I doubt the board is working with 0.12A only.
Uneless your meter doesn't show real values.
If you really get Link lED flashing on bootable USB, board should be starting.
In such case, why not checking for external video too?
But again my doubt, how the board will work without VCORE ([B]<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>)???[/B]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 50205"]I doubt the board is working with 0.12A only.
Uneless your meter doesn't show real values.
If you really get Link lED flashing on bootable USB, board should be starting.
In such case, why not checking for external video too?
But again my doubt, how the board will work without VCORE ([B]<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>)???[/B][/QUOTE]

Its the same usb c meter that rossmann uses and sells on his website. ([URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/index.php/ab4-usb-c-amp-meter.html"]https://store.rossmanngroup.com/inde...amp-meter.html[/URL])

Thats what I am confused by, there is a faint light on the mouse, not super bright.

I just checked for external video and there is none.

I am not sure why there is no vcore.

Are there any other rails I should post voltages or ohms readings for more information?

I am thinking about replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> just incase.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message: No VCore is going to be bad <CHIP>ISL95828</CHIP> aka the picture you showed or bad CPU especially with no liquid. My bet is CPU as USBC Macs happen to often be trash

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
As you get S3 and S0 votages, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is OK, don't touch it.
Apart of CPU VCORE, which other coils have no voltage?

20V/0.3A is other thing; normal value for working board.
Check VCORE at the same time, if pulse at least.

I didn't complain about meter; it fluctuates and you probably can't read all values...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 50214"]No VCore is going to be bad <CHIP>ISL95828</CHIP> aka the picture you showed or bad CPU especially with no liquid. My bet is CPU as USBC Macs happen to often be trash [/QUOTE]

I will purchase from his store the chip and replace it, there was some liquid damage around the backlight area that was repaired, mostly the caps were burnt.

<RESISTOR>R3772</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R3771</RESISTOR>, <CHIP>U3780</CHIP>, were replaced. <CAPACITOR>C8461</CAPACITOR> (and the other big ones were replaced)

Another spot that gets hot is the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, not hot but slightly warm with the FLIR. with your fingers its not recognizingly hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message:
"there was some liquid damage around the backlight area"
That's sounds like dead CPU.
There are many CPU data lines, which can be affected; even inside the board (internal copper layers).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCore, fan spins no post
threads.message: Oh yeah if liquid was near backlight, you could very likely have a bad CPU sadly :(
